animalOfTheDay.name: toad
facts: Toads are more terrestrial than frogs and are often found far from water.
Toads have dry, warty skin, while frogs have smooth, moist skin.
They secrete toxins from their skin to deter predators, which can be harmful if ingested.
Some toads, like the cane toad, have become invasive species in certain regions.

calendar.name: swordfish
facts: They can swim at speeds up to 60 mph, making them one of the fastest fish.
Swordfish can dive to depths of over 1,800 feet in search of food.
Their sword-like bill is used to slash at prey, stunning or injuring them.
Swordfish have a specialized organ that warms their eyes and brain, improving their vision in cold water.

calendar.name: tamarin
facts: They communicate through a variety of high-pitched vocalizations.
Tamarin monkeys are among the smallest primates, some weighing less than a pound.
They often give birth to twins, which is unusual for primates.
Tamarins have claw-like nails instead of flat nails like other monkeys.

calendar.name: tarsier
facts: They communicate using ultrasonic frequencies beyond human hearing.
Tarsiers are the only entirely carnivorous primates, eating insects, lizards, and small birds.
Tarsiers have the largest eyes relative to body size of any mammal.
They can rotate their heads nearly 180 degrees in each direction.

calendar.name: tasmanian devil
facts: Tasmanian devils are carnivorous marsupials native to Tasmania, Australia.
They are known for their ferocious screeches and powerful bite.
Tasmanian devils are solitary and nocturnal scavengers.
They are the largest carnivorous marsupial in the world.

calendar.name: termite
facts: Termites are more closely related to cockroaches than to ants.
They cultivate fungi in their nests as a food source.
Some termite mounds can be over 30 feet tall and contain millions of individuals.
Termite queens can live up to 50 years, making them among the longest-living insects.

calendar.name: tiger shark
facts: Tiger sharks are called 'garbage cans of the sea' because they'll eat almost anything.
They have unique, saw-like teeth that can cut through turtle shells.
Tiger sharks are one of the few shark species that can tolerate freshwater.
They are born with distinctive stripes that fade as they mature.

calendar.name: toad
facts: Toads are more terrestrial than frogs and are often found far from water.
They secrete toxins from their skin to deter predators, which can be harmful if ingested.
Toads have dry, warty skin, while frogs have smooth, moist skin.
Some toads, like the cane toad, have become invasive species in certain regions.

randomAnimals.name: gopher
facts: Gophers have cheek pouches for carrying food back to their burrows.
They rarely come above ground and can live their entire lives underground.
They can close their lips behind their front teeth to keep dirt out while digging.
Gophers can dig tunnels up to 800 feet long.

randomAnimals.name: wallaby
facts: Wallabies hop efficiently â€“ energy use doesn't increase with speed.
They practice embryonic diapause; pausing development until environmental conditions improve.
Wallabies cool by licking forearms; saliva evaporation lowers blood temperature.
Rock wallabies scale cliffs using textured soles and tail balancing.

randomAnimals.name: rabbit
facts: Their teeth never stop growing, so they must chew constantly to wear them down.
Rabbits perform joyful leaps called 'binkies' when happy or excited.
They have nearly 360-degree vision, allowing them to spot predators from almost any angle.
Rabbits are not rodents but belong to the order Lagomorpha, which includes hares and pikas.
